entry.title: Chapter 9: Community
entry.summary: In April of 2009, Yahoo! shut down GeoCities. Practically overnight, the once beloved service had its signup page replaced with a vague message announcing its closure. We have decided to discontinue the process of allowing new customers to sign up â€¦ The post Chapter 9: Community appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: The Rise Of Design Thinking As A Problem Solving Strategy
entry.summary: In the dynamic and unpredictable environments in which we work, even the most carefully crafted solutions can have a short shelf life. When we accept that our work is impermanent and our problem-solving abilities are limited, our goal can shift from delivering full solutions to developing tools that empower our users to adaptively design for themselves.

entry.title: v1.11.0
entry.summary:

Aggregate content from any YouTube channel rss url https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=<replace_with_channel_id> Videos are embedded via iframe and loading accelerated by youtube-lite-embed Ads are reduced thanks to YouTube's policy for embedded videos ðŸ™ƒ Works on mobile devices with butter smooth horizontal scroll. entry.title: Image To Text Conversion With React And Tesseract.js (OCR)
entry.summary: Do you have to process data manually because it is served through images or scanned documents? An image-to-text conversion makes it possible to extract text from images to automate the processing of texts on images, videos, and scanned documents. In this article, we look at how to convert an image to text with React and Tesseract.js(OCR), preprocess images, and deal with the limitations of Tesseract (OCR).

entry.title: Using the `outline` Property as a Collapsable Border
entry.summary: The outline property in CSS draws a line around the outside of an element. This is quite similar to the border property, the main exception being that outline isnâ€™t a part of the box model. It is often used for â€¦ The post Using the `outline` Property as a Collapsable Border appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.summary: What is TCP?TCP is an acronym for Transmission Control Protocol. It is a transport layer protocol that allows packets to be sent from one location to another. TCP is a connection-oriented protocol, which means it establishes the connection before any communication between the networkâ€™s computer units. Because we

entry.title: Machine Learning Specialisation Courses for Advanced ML Practitioners
entry.summary: Today, you donâ€™t need to go to a university or a college to pursue a career in machine learning or any data-driven domain. But you do need a plan and a roadmap to guide your studies. Once you have charted your own learning roadmap with a goal in mind,

entry.title: An Alternative Voice UI To Voice Assistants
entry.summary: Voice assistants are currently the most popular use case for voice user interfaces. However, due to the bad feedback loop resulting from voice assistants can only solve simple user tasks such as setting an alarm or playing music. In order for voice user interfaces to really break through, feedback to the user must be visual, not auditive.

entry.summary: Every programming language uses sorting algorithms. While programming languages have easy-to-use sorting methods, it can be helpful to understand how they work. entry.title: Client-Side Routing In Next.js
entry.summary: Next.js has a file-based routing system in which each page automatically becomes a route based on its file name. This article will guide you through almost everything you need to know about Routing in Next.js and point you in the direction of related topics and concepts.

entry.title: Equal Columns With Flexbox: Itâ€™s More Complicated Than You Might Think
entry.summary: As awesome as flexbox is, what itâ€™s doing under the hood is actually a little strange because, by default, it is doing two things at once. It first looks at the content size which is what we would get if by declaring width: max-content on an element. But on top of that, flex-shrink is also doing some work allowing the items to be smaller, but only if needed. Letâ€™s break those two down and see how they work together.
